Gasthaus gives plenty of reasons to indulge

From potato soup to Black Forest cake, German restaurant's dishes are the real deal

Gasthaus gives plenty of reasons to indulge

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 10:22 a.m. EST December 22, 2014

Rouladen with Rotkraut at Gasthaus in Louisville, KY. Dec. 16, 2014(Photo: Frankie Steele, Special to The CJ)

Story Highlights

  • Rating: 4 stars out of 4
  • Address: 4812 Brownsboro Center
  • Telephone: (502) 899-7177
1 CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Gasthaus is a treasure trove of food and overflowing fun.

I have never had the impression that the restaurant was "decorated" although there is barely an inch of space that isn't filled with an eye-catching detail. It is a wonderland of German memorabilia, photographs of the Greipel family proprietors, antiques, a cuckoo clock, servers in dirndls and, most importantly, whimsical mini-facades of chalets that divide the dining room into sections.

Annemarie Greipel may spend much of her day in the kitchen baking spectacular desserts, but at dinner she's front and center. To say that she greets guests is as much of an understatement as saying her Black Forest cake is a chocolate dessert. She welcomes and she bustles about and she makes you feel warmly at home. It's no act. She's the real thing, as is the food she, her husband Michael, and chef Jason Malone serve.

I'm not a newcomer to some good potato soup, but Gasthaus' potato soup ($6) made me realize I didn't know how extraordinarily luscious it could taste. Affluent with cream and pieces of sausage, it set a standard for which I'm sure no other potato soup will come close. Put it in a glass and it could become a cocktail.

Rouladen ($21.50) is a profusion of flavors rolled into one. I'm not speaking figuratively. Rolled beef is filled with bacon, onion and pickles. There was an absence of pickle in my first couple of bites. But, then, there it was, wrapped like a delightful surprise. Bacon and pickle are a wondrous meeting of flavors, especially when they're ensconced in meltingly tender slices of beef. Other beef entrees include gulasch ($20), stroganoff ($25) and sauerbraten ($21).

    Last SlideNext Slide

    There's a nice selection of poultry dishes: tenderloins with sauteed mushrooms ($18.50), ragout ($20), Cordon Bleu ($20) and the creamy sauced-Wiener Art ($17).

    Some entrees include spaetzle (squiggly egg noodles). For other entrees, you may order a side of your choice ($6.50), such as potato dumplings, sauerkraut, German potato salad or pan-fried potatoes. The rotkraut (red cabbage) I chose as my side for the rouladen was just as I had hoped. Was it sweet? Yes. Was it sour? Yes. Would I order it again? Yes, although I might again pair it with the potato dumplings, yet another side I felt not a modicum of guilt about ordering. It was not an evening for guilt, but one for indulgence and an embracing of all things deliciously comforting.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    60 West Bistro disappoints

    I don't think a trip to Gasthaus is complete without jäger schnitzel ($21.50). Neither did my son Alex, who ordered the dish, one that is a quintessential staple on most German restaurant menus. Not infrequently, a restaurant's jäger schnitzel is overpounded to the point it resembles a Manolo Blahnik that has pounded the pavement too many times. At Gasthaus, it's a perfect, undainty, gravied dish that's easy to fall in love with and impossible with which to fall out of love.

    There are two other pork schnitzels, rahm schnitzel ($20), in a creamy sauce, and zigeuner schnitzel ($21.50), in a sauce of sweet and sour mushrooms, bacon and red peppers. Veal dishes include wiener schnitzel ($23) and schnitzel a la Holstein ($25), a dish I have never eaten but that is on my must-try list at Gasthaus. I'm intrigued by sauteed veal topped by fried eggs, anchovies and capers.

    All good things have to come to an end. They came to an end in a very good way at Gasthaus, where the dessert selection ($8-$9.50) varies daily. From where I sat during dinner, I had a clear view of the desserts. For Greipel to display them so blatantly shows no mercy, at least to someone whose resistance is negligible. Of course, we could have declined dessert, but it wasn't a night to be a dessert martyr.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Review: Anoosh Bistro in Louisville, Kentucky is sublime

    Alex's apple strudel was flaky and plump with apples, and served with vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. I had ogled the Black Forest cake (or Schwarzwälder Kirsch Torte, as those in the know about German tortes would refer to it) far too long. Finally a piece of it was mine. The layers of the richest chocolate cake, cherries and oodles of whipped cream excessively expressed why it is one of the world's most famous desserts. I'm all for excess and fame.

    And I'm all for Gasthaus.

    You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com.Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.

    GASTHAUS

    ★★★★

    Address: 4812 Brownsboro Center

    Telephone: (502) 899-7177

    Web:gasthausdining.com

    Cuisine: German.

    Alcohol: Wine, beer and Schnapps.

    Vegetarian: Yes.

    Price range: Moderate to expensive.

    Reservations: Yes.

    Credit cards: V, MC, D

    Children's menu: Yes.

    Smoking: No.

    Access: The restaurant appears to be fully accessible for people using wheelchairs without assistance.

    Hours: Tuesday-Saturday, 6-9:30 p.m.

    ★★★★ outstanding

    ★★★½ excellent

    ★★★☆ very good

    ★★½☆ good

    ★★☆☆ fair

    ★☆☆☆ poor
